intro: Brassica mesopotamica, commonly known as wild mustard, is an annual flowering plant native to the Middle East and Central Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other cruciferous plants. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, featuring alternate, pinnately lobed leaves and small yellow flowers arranged in racemes. Its seeds are small, oblong, and often contain a high concentration of glucosinolates, which are characteristic of the Brassica genus. This species is often found in disturbed soils and is sometimes considered a weed in agricultural settings.
